column2:
Convinced as Elizabeth now was that Miss Bingley’s dislike of her had
originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome
her appearance at Pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know
with how much civility on that lady’s side the acquaintance would now
be renewed.
column3: convinced as elizabeth now was that miss bingley's dislike of her had originated in jealousy, she could not help feeling how very unwelcome her appearance at pemberley must be to her, and was curious to know with how much civility on that lady's side the acquaintance would now be renewed.

column2:
On reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon,
whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer.
column3: on reaching the house, they were shown through the hall into the saloon, whose northern aspect rendered it delightful for summer.

column2:
Its windows,
opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody
hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and Spanish chestnuts
which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.
column3: its windows, opening to the ground, admitted a most refreshing view of the high woody hills behind the house, and of the beautiful oaks and spanish chestnuts which were scattered over the intermediate lawn.

column2:
In this room they were received by Miss Darcy, who was sitting there
with Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in
London.
column3: in this room they were received by miss darcy, who was sitting there with mrs. hurst and miss bingley, and the lady with whom she lived in london.

column2:
Georgiana’s reception of them was very civil, but attended with
all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the
fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves
inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved.
column3: georgiana's reception of them was very civil, but attended with all that embarrassment which, though proceeding from shyness and the fear of doing wrong, would easily give to those who felt themselves inferior the belief of her being proud and reserved.

column2:
Mrs. Gardiner and
her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.
column3: mrs. gardiner and her niece, however, did her justice, and pitied her.

column2:
By Mrs. Hurst and Miss Bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and
on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be,
succeeded for a few moments.
column3: by mrs. hurst and miss bingley they were noticed only by a courtesy; and on their being seated, a pause, awkward as such pauses must always be, succeeded for a few moments.

column2:
It was first broken by Mrs. Annesley, a
genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind
of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the
others; and between her and Mrs. Gardiner, with occasional help from
Elizabeth, the conversation was carried on.
column3: it was first broken by mrs. annesley, a genteel, agreeable-looking woman, whose endeavour to introduce some kind of discourse proved her to be more truly well-bred than either of the others; and between her and mrs. gardiner, with occasional help from elizabeth, the conversation was carried on.

column2:
Miss Darcy looked as if she
wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a
short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.
column3: miss darcy looked as if she wished for courage enough to join in it; and sometimes did venture a short sentence, when there was least danger of its being heard.

column2:
Elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by Miss Bingley,
and that she could not speak a word, especially to Miss Darcy, without
calling her attention.
column3: elizabeth soon saw that she was herself closely watched by miss bingley, and that she could not speak a word, especially to miss darcy, without calling her attention.

column2:
This observation would not have prevented her
from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an
inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity
of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her.
column3: this observation would not have prevented her from trying to talk to the latter, had they not been seated at an inconvenient distance; but she was not sorry to be spared the necessity of saying much: her own thoughts were employing her.

column2:
She expected every
moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she
feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether
she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine.
column3: she expected every moment that some of the gentlemen would enter the room: she wished, she feared, that the master of the house might be amongst them; and whether she wished or feared it most, she could scarcely determine.

column2:
After
sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing Miss
Bingley’s voice, Elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold
inquiry after the health of her family.
column3: after sitting in this manner a quarter of an hour, without hearing miss bingley's voice, elizabeth was roused by receiving from her a cold inquiry after the health of her family.

column2:
She answered with equal
indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.
column3: she answered with equal indifference and brevity, and the other said no more.

column2:
The next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the
entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the
finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a
significant look and smile from Mrs. Annesley to Miss Darcy had been
given, to remind her of her post.
column3: the next variation which their visit afforded was produced by the entrance of servants with cold meat, cake, and a variety of all the finest fruits in season; but this did not take place till after many a significant look and smile from mrs. annesley to miss darcy had been given, to remind her of her post.

column2:
There was now employment for the whole
party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the
beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected
them round the table.
column3: there was now employment for the whole party; for though they could not all talk, they could all eat; and the beautiful pyramids of grapes, nectarines, and peaches, soon collected them round the table.

column2:
While thus engaged, Elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether
she most feared or wished for the appearance of Mr. Darcy, by the
feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but
a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to
regret that he came.
column3: while thus engaged, elizabeth had a fair opportunity of deciding whether she most feared or wished for the appearance of mr. darcy, by the feelings which prevailed on his entering the room; and then, though but a moment before she had believed her wishes to predominate, she began to regret that he came.

column2:
He had been some time with Mr. Gardiner, who, with two or three other
gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him
only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to
Georgiana that morning.
column3: he had been some time with mr. gardiner, who, with two or three other gentlemen from the house, was engaged by the river; and had left him only on learning that the ladies of the family intended a visit to georgiana that morning.

column2:
No sooner did he appear, than Elizabeth wisely
resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more
necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she
saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them,
and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour
when he first came into the room.
column3: no sooner did he appear, than elizabeth wisely resolved to be perfectly easy and unembarrassed;--a resolution the more necessary to be made, but perhaps not the more easily kept, because she saw that the suspicions of the whole party were awakened against them, and that there was scarcely an eye which did not watch his behaviour when he first came into the room.

column2:
In no countenance was attentive
curiosity so strongly marked as in Miss Bingley’s, in spite of the
smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its
objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions
to Mr. Darcy were by no means over.
column3: in no countenance was attentive curiosity so strongly marked as in miss bingley's, in spite of the smiles which overspread her face whenever she spoke to one of its objects; for jealousy had not yet made her desperate, and her attentions to mr. darcy were by no means over.

column2:
Miss Darcy, on her brother’s
entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and Elizabeth saw that he
was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded,
as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.
column3: miss darcy, on her brother's entrance, exerted herself much more to talk; and elizabeth saw that he was anxious for his sister and herself to get acquainted, and forwarded, as much as possible, every attempt at conversation on either side.

column2:
Miss
Bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the
first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,--

“Pray, Miss Eliza, are not the ----shire militia removed from Meryton?
column3: miss bingley saw all this likewise; and, in the imprudence of anger, took the first opportunity of saying, with sneering civility,-- "pray, miss eliza, are not the ----shire militia removed from meryton?

column2:
They must be a great loss to your family.”

In Darcy’s presence she dared not mention Wickham’s name: but Elizabeth
instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the
various recollections connected with him gave her a moment’s distress;
but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she
presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.
column3: they must be a great loss to your family." in darcy's presence she dared not mention wickham's name: but elizabeth instantly comprehended that he was uppermost in her thoughts; and the various recollections connected with him gave her a moment's distress; but, exerting herself vigorously to repel the ill-natured attack, she presently answered the question in a tolerably disengaged tone.

column2:
While
she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her Darcy with a heightened
complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with
confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes.
column3: while she spoke, an involuntary glance showed her darcy with a heightened complexion, earnestly looking at her, and his sister overcome with confusion, and unable to lift up her eyes.

column2:
Had Miss Bingley known what
pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would have
refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose
Elizabeth, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed
her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in
Darcy’s opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies
and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected with
that corps.
column3: had miss bingley known what pain she was then giving her beloved friend, she undoubtedly would have refrained from the hint; but she had merely intended to discompose elizabeth, by bringing forward the idea of a man to whom she believed her partial, to make her betray a sensibility which might injure her in darcy's opinion, and, perhaps, to remind the latter of all the follies and absurdities by which some part of her family were connected with that corps.

column2:
Not a syllable had ever reached her of Miss Darcy’s
meditated elopement.
column3: not a syllable had ever reached her of miss darcy's meditated elopement.

column2:
To no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy
was possible, except to Elizabeth; and from all Bingley’s connections
her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish
which Elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming
hereafter her own.
column3: to no creature had it been revealed, where secrecy was possible, except to elizabeth; and from all bingley's connections her brother was particularly anxious to conceal it, from that very wish which elizabeth had long ago attributed to him, of their becoming hereafter her own.

column2:
He had certainly formed such a plan; and without
meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from Miss
Bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern
for the welfare of his friend.
column3: he had certainly formed such a plan; and without meaning that it should affect his endeavour to separate him from miss bennet, it is probable that it might add something to his lively concern for the welfare of his friend.

column2:
Elizabeth’s collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and
as Miss Bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to
Wickham, Georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able
to speak any more.
column3: elizabeth's collected behaviour, however, soon quieted his emotion; and as miss bingley, vexed and disappointed, dared not approach nearer to wickham, georgiana also recovered in time, though not enough to be able to speak any more.

column2:
Her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely
recollected her interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which
had been designed to turn his thoughts from Elizabeth, seemed to have
fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.
column3: her brother, whose eye she feared to meet, scarcely recollected her interest in the affair; and the very circumstance which had been designed to turn his thoughts from elizabeth, seemed to have fixed them on her more and more cheerfully.

column2:
Their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above
mentioned; and while Mr. Darcy was attending them to their carriage,
Miss Bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on Elizabeth’s
person, behaviour, and dress.
column3: their visit did not continue long after the question and answer above mentioned; and while mr. darcy was attending them to their carriage, miss bingley was venting her feelings in criticisms on elizabeth's person, behaviour, and dress.

column2: But Georgiana would not join her.
column3: but georgiana would not join her.

column2:
Her
brother’s recommendation was enough to insure her favour: his judgment
could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of Elizabeth, as to leave
Georgiana without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and
amiable.
column3: her brother's recommendation was enough to insure her favour: his judgment could not err; and he had spoken in such terms of elizabeth, as to leave georgiana without the power of finding her otherwise than lovely and amiable.

column2:
When Darcy returned to the saloon, Miss Bingley could not help
repeating to him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.
column3: when darcy returned to the saloon, miss bingley could not help repeating to him some part of what she had been saying to his sister.

column2:
“How very ill Eliza Bennet looks this morning, Mr. Darcy,” she cried: “I
never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since the winter.
column3: "how very ill eliza bennet looks this morning, mr. darcy," she cried: "i never in my life saw anyone so much altered as she is since the winter.

column2: She is grown so brown and coarse!
column3: she is grown so brown and coarse!

column2:
Louisa and I were agreeing that we
should not have known her again.”

However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented
himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than
her being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the
summer.
column3: louisa and i were agreeing that we should not have known her again." however little mr. darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than her being rather tanned,--no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.

column2:
“For my own part,” she rejoined, “I must confess that I never could see
any beauty in her.
column3: "for my own part," she rejoined, "i must confess that i never could see any beauty in her.

column2:
Her face is too thin; her complexion has no
brilliancy; and her features are not at all handsome.
column3: her face is too thin
column4: her complexion has no brilliancy
column5: and her features are not at all handsome.

column2:
Her nose wants
character; there is nothing marked in its lines.
column3: her nose wants character
column4: there is nothing marked in its lines.

column2:
Her teeth are
tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which
have sometimes been called so fine, I never could perceive anything
extraordinary in them.
column3: her teeth are tolerable, but not out of the common way; and as for her eyes, which have sometimes been called so fine, i never could perceive anything extraordinary in them.

column2:
They have a sharp, shrewish look, which I do not
like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency
without fashion, which is intolerable.”

Persuaded as Miss Bingley was that Darcy admired Elizabeth, this was not
the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always
wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the
success she expected.
column3: they have a sharp, shrewish look, which i do not like at all; and in her air altogether, there is a self-sufficiency without fashion, which is intolerable." persuaded as miss bingley was that darcy admired elizabeth, this was not the best method of recommending herself; but angry people are not always wise; and in seeing him at last look somewhat nettled, she had all the success she expected.

column2:
He was resolutely silent, however; and, from a
determination of making him speak, she continued,--

“I remember, when we first knew her in Hertfordshire, how amazed we all
were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and I particularly recollect
your saying one night, after they had been dining at Netherfield, ‘_She_
a beauty!
column3: he was resolutely silent, however; and, from a determination of making him speak, she continued,-- "i remember, when we first knew her in hertfordshire, how amazed we all were to find that she was a reputed beauty; and i particularly recollect your saying one night, after they had been dining at netherfield, '_she a beauty!

column2:
I should as soon call her mother a wit.’ But afterwards she
seemed to improve on you, and I believe you thought her rather pretty at
one time.”

“Yes,” replied Darcy, who could contain himself no longer, “but that_
was only when I first knew her; for it is many months since I have
considered her as one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance.”

He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of
having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.
column3: i should as soon call her mother a wit.' but afterwards she seemed to improve on you, and i believe you thought her rather pretty at one time." column2:
Mrs. Gardiner and Elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their
visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them
both.
column3: mrs. gardiner and elizabeth talked of all that had occurred during their visit, as they returned, except what had particularly interested them both.

column2:
The looks and behaviour of everybody they had seen were discussed,
except of the person who had mostly engaged their attention.
column3: the looks and behaviour of everybody they had seen were discussed, except of the person who had mostly engaged their attention.

column2:
They talked
of his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit, of everything but
himself; yet Elizabeth was longing to know what Mrs. Gardiner thought of
him, and Mrs. Gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece’s
beginning the subject.
column3: they talked of his sister, his friends, his house, his fruit, of everything but himself; yet elizabeth was longing to know what mrs. gardiner thought of him, and mrs. gardiner would have been highly gratified by her niece's beginning the subject.

column2: Chapter XLVI.
column3: chapter xlvi.

column2:
Elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from
Jane on their first arrival at Lambton; and this disappointment had been
renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but on
the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the
receipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that
it had been mis-sent elsewhere.
column3: elizabeth had been a good deal disappointed in not finding a letter from jane on their first arrival at lambton; and this disappointment had been renewed on each of the mornings that had now been spent there; but on the third her repining was over, and her sister justified, by the receipt of two letters from her at once, on one of which was marked that it had been mis-sent elsewhere.

column2:
Elizabeth was not surprised at it, as
Jane had written the direction remarkably ill.
column3: elizabeth was not surprised at it, as jane had written the direction remarkably ill.

column2:
They had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her
uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by
themselves.
column3: they had just been preparing to walk as the letters came in; and her uncle and aunt, leaving her to enjoy them in quiet, set off by themselves.

column2:
The one mis-sent must be first attended to; it had been
written five days ago.
column3: the one mis-sent must be first attended to
column4: it had been written five days ago.

column2:
The beginning contained an account of all their
little parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded;
but the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident
agitation, gave more important intelligence.
column3: the beginning contained an account of all their little parties and engagements, with such news as the country afforded; but the latter half, which was dated a day later, and written in evident agitation, gave more important intelligence.

column2:
It was to this effect:--

“Since writing the above, dearest Lizzy, something has occurred of a
most unexpected and serious nature; but I am afraid of alarming you--be
assured that we are all well.
column3: it was to this effect:-- "since writing the above, dearest lizzy, something has occurred of a most unexpected and serious nature; but i am afraid of alarming you--be assured that we are all well.

column2: What I have to say relates to poor Lydia.
column3: what i have to say relates to poor lydia.

column2:
An express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed,
from Colonel Forster, to inform us that she was gone off to Scotland
with one of his officers; to own the truth, with Wickham!
column3: an express came at twelve last night, just as we were all gone to bed, from colonel forster, to inform us that she was gone off to scotland with one of his officers; to own the truth, with wickham!

column2:
Imagine our
surprise.
column3: imagine our surprise.

column2: To Kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.
column3: to kitty, however, it does not seem so wholly unexpected.

column2:
I am
very, very sorry.
column3: i am very, very sorry.

column2: So imprudent a match on both sides!
column3: so imprudent a match on both sides!

column2:
But I am willing
to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.
column3: but i am willing to hope the best, and that his character has been misunderstood.

column2:
Thoughtless and indiscreet I can easily believe him, but this step (and
let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart.
column3: thoughtless and indiscreet i can easily believe him, but this step (and let us rejoice over it) marks nothing bad at heart.

column2:
His choice is
disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.
column3: his choice is disinterested at least, for he must know my father can give her nothing.

column2: Our poor mother is sadly grieved.
column3: our poor mother is sadly grieved.

column2: My father bears it better.
column3: my father bears it better.

column2:
How
thankful am I, that we never let them know what has been said against
him; we must forget it ourselves.
column3: how thankful am i, that we never let them know what has been said against him; we must forget it ourselves.

column2:
They were off Saturday night about
twelve, as is conjectured, but were not missed till yesterday morning at
eight.

column2: The express was sent off directly.
column3: the express was sent off directly.

column2:
My dear Lizzy, they must have
passed within ten miles of us.
column3: my dear lizzy, they must have passed within ten miles of us.

column2:
Colonel Forster gives us reason to expect
him here soon.
column3: colonel forster gives us reason to expect him here soon.

column2:
Lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of
their intention.
column3: lydia left a few lines for his wife, informing her of their intention.

I must conclude, for I cannot be long from my poor
mother.

I am afraid you will not be able to make it out, but I hardly
know what I have written.”

Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing
what she felt, Elizabeth, on finishing this letter, instantly seized the
other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it
had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.

column2:
“By this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; I
wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my
head is so bewildered that I cannot answer for being coherent.
column3: "by this time, my dearest sister, you have received my hurried letter; i wish this may be more intelligible, but though not confined for time, my head is so bewildered that i cannot answer for being coherent.

column2:

Lizzy, I hardly know what I would write, but I have bad news for you,
and it cannot be delayed.
column3: dearest lizzy, i hardly know what i would write, but i have bad news for you, and it cannot be delayed.

column2:
Imprudent as a marriage between Mr. Wickham
and our poor Lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has
taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone
to Scotland.
column3: imprudent as a marriage between mr. wickham and our poor lydia would be, we are now anxious to be assured it has taken place, for there is but too much reason to fear they are not gone to scotland.

Colonel Forster came yesterday, having left Brighton the
day before, not many hours after the express.

column2:
Though Lydia’s short
letter to Mrs. F. gave them to understand that they were going to Gretna
Green, something was dropped by Denny expressing his belief that W.
never intended to go there, or to marry Lydia at all, which was repeated
to Colonel F., who, instantly taking the alarm, set off from B.,
intending to trace their route.

He did trace them easily to Clapham, but
no farther; for on entering that place, they removed into a
hackney-coach, and dismissed the chaise that brought them from Epsom.

inquiry on that side London, Colonel F. came on into Hertfordshire,

and Hatfield, but without any success,--no such people had been seen to

circumstances might make it more eligible for them to be married

which is not likely, can I suppose her so lost to everything?

Then perceiving in Elizabeth no inclination of replying, she added,
“Unhappy as the event must be for Lydia, we may draw from it this useful
lesson:--that loss of virtue in a female is irretrievable, that one
false step involves her in endless ruin, that her reputation is no less
brittle than it is beautiful, and that she cannot be too much guarded in
her behaviour towards the undeserving of the other sex.”

little copse.”

and ran across the lawn after their father, who was deliberately
pursuing his way towards a small wood on one side of the paddock.

Pray write instantly, and let me understand it--unless it is,
for very cogent reasons, to remain in the secrecy which Lydia seems to
think necessary; and then I must endeavour to be satisfied with
ignorance.”

“Not that I shall_, though,” she added to herself, and she finished the
letter; “and, my dear aunt, if you do not tell me in an honourable
manner, I shall certainly be reduced to tricks and stratagems to find it
out.”

Jane’s delicate sense of honour would not allow her to speak to
Elizabeth privately of what Lydia had let fall; Elizabeth was glad of
it:--till it appeared whether her inquiries would receive any
satisfaction, she had rather be without a confidante.

From an unwillingness to confess how much her intimacy with Mr. Darcy
had been overrated, Elizabeth had never yet answered Mrs. Gardiner’s
long letter; but now, having that to communicate which she knew would
be most welcome, she was almost ashamed to find that her uncle and aunt
had already lost three days of happiness, and immediately wrote as
follows:--

“I would have thanked you before, my dear aunt, as I ought to have done,
for your long, kind, satisfactory detail of particulars; but, to say the
truth, I was too cross to write.

column2:
Console Lady Catherine as well as
     you can.
column3: console lady catherine as well as you can.

column2: But, if I were you, I would stand by the nephew.
column3: but, if i were you, i would stand by the nephew.

column2:
He has
     more to give.
column3: he has more to give.

column2: “Yours sincerely,” etc.
column3: "yours sincerely," etc.

column2:
Miss Bingley’s congratulations to her brother on his approaching
marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere.
column3: miss bingley's congratulations to her brother on his approaching marriage were all that was affectionate and insincere.

column2:
She wrote even to
Jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former
professions of regard.
column3: she wrote even to jane on the occasion, to express her delight, and repeat all her former professions of regard.

column2:
Jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and
though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much
kinder answer than she knew was deserved.
column3: jane was not deceived, but she was affected; and though feeling no reliance on her, could not help writing her a much kinder answer than she knew was deserved.

column2:
The joy which Miss Darcy expressed on receiving similar information was
as sincere as her brother’s in sending it.
column3: the joy which miss darcy expressed on receiving similar information was as sincere as her brother's in sending it.

column2:
Four sides of paper were
insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of
being loved by her sister.
column3: four sides of paper were insufficient to contain all her delight, and all her earnest desire of being loved by her sister.

column2:
Before any answer could arrive from Mr. Collins, or any congratulations
to Elizabeth from his wife, the Longbourn family heard that the
Collinses were come themselves to Lucas Lodge.
column3: before any answer could arrive from mr. collins, or any congratulations to elizabeth from his wife, the longbourn family heard that the collinses were come themselves to lucas lodge.

column2:
The reason of this
sudden removal was soon evident.
column3: the reason of this sudden removal was soon evident.

column2:
Lady Catherine had been rendered so
exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew’s letter, that
Charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till
the storm was blown over.
column3: lady catherine had been rendered so exceedingly angry by the contents of her nephew's letter, that charlotte, really rejoicing in the match, was anxious to get away till the storm was blown over.

column2:
At such a moment, the arrival of her friend
was a sincere pleasure to Elizabeth, though in the course of their
meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she
saw Mr. Darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her
husband.
column3: at such a moment, the arrival of her friend was a sincere pleasure to elizabeth, though in the course of their meetings she must sometimes think the pleasure dearly bought, when she saw mr. darcy exposed to all the parading and obsequious civility of her husband.

column2: He bore it, however, with admirable calmness.
column3: he bore it, however, with admirable calmness.

column2:
He could even
listen to Sir William Lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away
the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all
meeting frequently at St. James’s, with very decent composure.
column3: he could even listen to sir william lucas, when he complimented him on carrying away the brightest jewel of the country, and expressed his hopes of their all meeting frequently at st. james's, with very decent composure.

column2:
If he did
shrug his shoulders, it was not till Sir William was out of sight.
column3: if he did shrug his shoulders, it was not till sir william was out of sight.

column2:
Mrs. Philips’s vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his
forbearance; and though Mrs. Philips, as well as her sister, stood in
too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which Bingley’s
good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she did speak, she must be
vulgar.
column3: mrs. philips's vulgarity was another, and, perhaps, a greater tax on his forbearance; and though mrs. philips, as well as her sister, stood in too much awe of him to speak with the familiarity which bingley's good-humour encouraged; yet, whenever she did speak, she must be vulgar.

column2:
Nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at
all likely to make her more elegant.
column3: nor was her respect for him, though it made her more quiet, at all likely to make her more elegant.

column2:
Elizabeth did all she could to
shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to
keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might
converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings
arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its
pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward
with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so
little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their
family party at Pemberley.
column3: elizabeth did all she could to shield him from the frequent notice of either, and was ever anxious to keep him to herself, and to those of her family with whom he might converse without mortification; and though the uncomfortable feelings arising from all this took from the season of courtship much of its pleasure, it added to the hope of the future; and she looked forward with delight to the time when they should be removed from society so little pleasing to either, to all the comfort and elegance of their family party at pemberley.

column2: CHAPTER LXI.
column3: chapter lxi.

column2:
Happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which Mrs. Bennet got
rid of her two most deserving daughters.
column3: happy for all her maternal feelings was the day on which mrs. bennet got rid of her two most deserving daughters.

column2:
With what delighted pride she
afterwards visited Mrs. Bingley, and talked of Mrs. Darcy, may be
guessed.
column3: with what delighted pride she afterwards visited mrs. bingley, and talked of mrs. darcy, may be guessed.

column2:
I wish I could say, for the sake of her family, that the
accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of
her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible,
amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps,
it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic
felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous
and invariably silly.
column3: i wish i could say, for the sake of her family, that the accomplishment of her earnest desire in the establishment of so many of her children produced so happy an effect as to make her a sensible, amiable, well-informed woman for the rest of her life; though, perhaps, it was lucky for her husband, who might not have relished domestic felicity in so unusual a form, that she still was occasionally nervous and invariably silly.

column2:
Mr. Bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly; his affection for her
drew him oftener from home than anything else could do.
column3: mr. bennet missed his second daughter exceedingly
column4: his affection for her drew him oftener from home than anything else could do.

column2:
He delighted in
going to Pemberley, especially when he was least expected.
column3: he delighted in going to pemberley, especially when he was least expected.

column2: Mr. Bingley and Jane remained at Netherfield only a twelvemonth.
column3: mr. bingley and jane remained at netherfield only a twelvemonth.

column2:
So near
a vicinity to her mother and Meryton relations was not desirable even to
_his easy temper, or her affectionate heart.
column3: so near a vicinity to her mother and meryton relations was not desirable even to his easy temper, or her affectionate heart.

column2:
The darling wish of his
sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county
to Derbyshire; and Jane and Elizabeth, in addition to every other source
of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.
column3: the darling wish of his sisters was then gratified: he bought an estate in a neighbouring county to derbyshire; and jane and elizabeth, in addition to every other source of happiness, were within thirty miles of each other.

column2:
Kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with
her two elder sisters.
column3: kitty, to her very material advantage, spent the chief of her time with her two elder sisters.

column2:
In society so superior to what she had generally
known, her improvement was great.
column3: in society so superior to what she had generally known, her improvement was great.

column2:
She was not of so ungovernable a
temper as Lydia; and, removed from the influence of Lydia’s example, she
became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less
ignorant, and less insipid.
column3: she was not of so ungovernable a temper as lydia; and, removed from the influence of lydia's example, she became, by proper attention and management, less irritable, less ignorant, and less insipid.

column2:
From the further disadvantage of Lydia’s
society she was of course carefully kept; and though Mrs. Wickham
frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of
balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.
column3: from the further disadvantage of lydia's society she was of course carefully kept; and though mrs. wickham frequently invited her to come and stay with her, with the promise of balls and young men, her father would never consent to her going.

column2:
Mary was the only daughter who remained at home; and she was necessarily
drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by Mrs. Bennet’s being quite
unable to sit alone.
column3: mary was the only daughter who remained at home
column4: and she was necessarily drawn from the pursuit of accomplishments by mrs. bennet's being quite unable to sit alone.

column2:
Mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but
she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no
longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters’ beauty and her own,
it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without
much reluctance.
column3: mary was obliged to mix more with the world, but she could still moralize over every morning visit; and as she was no longer mortified by comparisons between her sisters' beauty and her own, it was suspected by her father that she submitted to the change without much reluctance.

column2:
As for Wickham and Lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from
the marriage of her sisters.
column3: as for wickham and lydia, their characters suffered no revolution from the marriage of her sisters.

column2:
He bore with philosophy the conviction that
Elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude
and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of
everything, was not wholly without hope that Darcy might yet be
prevailed on to make his fortune.
column3: he bore with philosophy the conviction that elizabeth must now become acquainted with whatever of his ingratitude and falsehood had before been unknown to her; and, in spite of everything, was not wholly without hope that darcy might yet be prevailed on to make his fortune.

column2:
The congratulatory letter which
Elizabeth received from Lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by
his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished.
column3: the congratulatory letter which elizabeth received from lydia on her marriage explained to her that, by his wife at least, if not by himself, such a hope was cherished.

column2:
The
letter was to this effect:--

     /* “My dear Lizzy, */

     “I wish you joy.
column3: the letter was to this effect:-- /* "my dear lizzy, */ "i wish you joy.

column2:
If you love Mr. Darcy half so well as I do my dear
     Wickham, you must be very happy.
column3: if you love mr. darcy half so well as i do my dear wickham, you must be very happy.

column2:
It is a great comfort to have you
     so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, I hope you will
     think of us.
column3: it is a great comfort to have you so rich; and when you have nothing else to do, i hope you will think of us.

column2:
I am sure Wickham would like a place at court very
     much; and I do not think we shall have quite money enough to live
     upon without some help.
column3: i am sure wickham would like a place at court very much
column4: and i do not think we shall have quite money enough to live upon without some help.

column2:
Any place would do of about three or four
     hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to Mr. Darcy about it,
     if you had rather not.
column3: any place would do of about three or four hundred a year; but, however, do not speak to mr. darcy about it, if you had rather not.

column2: “Yours,” etc.
column3: "yours," etc.

column2:
As it happened that Elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in
her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.
column3: as it happened that elizabeth had much rather not, she endeavoured in her answer to put an end to every entreaty and expectation of the kind.

column2:
Such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice
of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she
frequently sent them.
column3: such relief, however, as it was in her power to afford, by the practice of what might be called economy in her own private expenses, she frequently sent them.

column2:
It had always been evident to her that such an
income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in
their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to
their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either Jane or
herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards
discharging their bills.
column3: it had always been evident to her that such an income as theirs, under the direction of two persons so extravagant in their wants, and heedless of the future, must be very insufficient to their support; and whenever they changed their quarters, either jane or herself were sure of being applied to for some little assistance towards discharging their bills.

column2:
Their manner of living, even when the
restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the
extreme.
column3: their manner of living, even when the restoration of peace dismissed them to a home, was unsettled in the extreme.

column2:
They were always moving from place to place in quest of a
cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought.
column3: they were always moving from place to place in quest of a cheap situation, and always spending more than they ought.

column2:
His affection
for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and,
in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to
reputation which her marriage had given her.
column3: his affection for her soon sunk into indifference: hers lasted a little longer; and, in spite of her youth and her manners, she retained all the claims to reputation which her marriage had given her.

column2:
Though Darcy could never
receive him at Pemberley, yet, for Elizabeth’s sake, he assisted him
further in his profession.
column3: though darcy could never receive him at pemberley, yet, for elizabeth's sake, he assisted him further in his profession.

column2:
Lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when
her husband was gone to enjoy himself in London or Bath; and with the
Bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even
Bingley’s good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk_
of giving them a hint to be gone.
column3: lydia was occasionally a visitor there, when her husband was gone to enjoy himself in london or bath; and with the bingleys they both of them frequently stayed so long, that even bingley's good-humour was overcome, and he proceeded so far as to talk of giving them a hint to be gone.

column2:
Miss Bingley was very deeply mortified by Darcy’s marriage; but as she
thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at Pemberley, she
dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of Georgiana, almost as
attentive to Darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility
to Elizabeth.
column3: miss bingley was very deeply mortified by darcy's marriage; but as she thought it advisable to retain the right of visiting at pemberley, she dropped all her resentment; was fonder than ever of georgiana, almost as attentive to darcy as heretofore, and paid off every arrear of civility to elizabeth.

column2:
Pemberley was now Georgiana’s home; and the attachment of the sisters
was exactly what Darcy had hoped to see.
column3: pemberley was now georgiana's home
column4: and the attachment of the sisters was exactly what darcy had hoped to see.

column2:
They were able to love each
other, even as well as they intended.
column3: they were able to love each other, even as well as they intended.

column2:
Georgiana had the highest opinion
in the world of Elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an
astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of
talking to her brother.
column3: georgiana had the highest opinion in the world of elizabeth; though at first she often listened with an astonishment bordering on alarm at her lively, sportive manner of talking to her brother.

column2:
He, who had always inspired in herself a respect
which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open
pleasantry.
column3: he, who had always inspired in herself a respect which almost overcame her affection, she now saw the object of open pleasantry.

column2:
Her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in
her way.
column3: her mind received knowledge which had never before fallen in her way.

column2:
By Elizabeth’s instructions she began to comprehend that a
woman may take liberties with her husband, which a brother will not
always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.
column3: by elizabeth's instructions she began to comprehend that a woman may take liberties with her husband, which a brother will not always allow in a sister more than ten years younger than himself.

column2:
Lady Catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew;
and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in
her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him
language so very abusive, especially of Elizabeth, that for some time
all intercourse was at an end.
column3: lady catherine was extremely indignant on the marriage of her nephew; and as she gave way to all the genuine frankness of her character, in her reply to the letter which announced its arrangement, she sent him language so very abusive, especially of elizabeth, that for some time all intercourse was at an end.

column2:
But at length, by Elizabeth’s persuasion,
he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation;
and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her
resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity
to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on
them at Pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had
received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the
visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.
column3: but at length, by elizabeth's persuasion, he was prevailed on to overlook the offence, and seek a reconciliation; and, after a little further resistance on the part of his aunt, her resentment gave way, either to her affection for him, or her curiosity to see how his wife conducted herself; and she condescended to wait on them at pemberley, in spite of that pollution which its woods had received, not merely from the presence of such a mistress, but the visits of her uncle and aunt from the city.

column2: With the Gardiners they were always on the most intimate terms.
column3: with the gardiners they were always on the most intimate terms.

column2:
Darcy,
as well as Elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever
sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing
her into Derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
column3: darcy, as well as elizabeth, really loved them; and they were both ever sensible of the warmest gratitude towards the persons who, by bringing her into derbyshire, had been the means of uniting them.
